body:
Ref: https://docs.perl6.org/language/nativecall#Passing_and_Returning_Values
 
The docs say there is no support for calling C functions with "int" because Perl6's "int" is not guaranteed to be the same size as a C int.  The docs list other platform-dependent-size types which _are_ supported,
such as "long", "longlong" and "ulong", but emphaticically say:

    "Don't use Perl 6 native types like int or num, as they don't have to 
    correspond to the local C equivalent (e.g., Perl 6's int can be 8 bytes 
    but C's int is only 4 bytes)."

This is pretty seriously confusing, IMO, and will forever cause programmers to write non-portable NativeCall interfaces.  

I'm wondering *why* this is the case, i.e., that a P6 "int" can not be guaranteed to match "int" in C?  Does perl6 internally use "int" in its implementation, or does the P6 language spec specify a minimum size?

If P6 "int" really must not necessarily match C "int", then:

    1) P6 should define another so-called native type which _is_ 
       guaranteed to be a "C int" on the execution platform; and

    2) Use of "int" in a CStruct, or similar context should cause an error
       to protect programmers from thinking they are writing portable code.

(Also: Need support for C "unsigned" a.k.a. "unsigned int")

Note: In C, "int" and "unsigned", have a platform-dependent size, ultimately determined by the C compiler & compile-time-options.

ANSI C99 specifies that "int" may have any size >= 16 bits.
title: NativeCall has no portable support for C "int" (?)
